M is the midpoint of line AB.

OP bisects the angle AOB.

OP is the bisector of angle AOB.
Every angle has an angle bisector.
A straight line can be drawn from any point to any other point.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle AOC and angle DOB are called vertically opposite angles.
If lines AB and CD cut one another at point O, then angle AOC and angle DOB are called vertically opposite angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle AOD and angle COB are called vertically opposite angles.
If lines AB and CD cut one another at point O, then angle AOD and angle COB are called vertically opposite angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle AOC and angle AOD are adjacent angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle BOC and angle BOD are adjacent angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle DOA and angle DOB are adjacent angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angle COA and angle COB are adjacent angles.
If AB is straight line and O is point on AB, then angle AOB is called a straight angle.
Sum of two right angles is a straight angle.
If angles AOP and BOP are two right angles then their sum angle AOB is a straight angle.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angles AOC and AOD are adjacent angles on the same side of CD.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angles BOC and BOD are adjacent angles on the same side of CD.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angles DOA and DOB are adjacent angles on the same side of AB.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angles COA and COB are adjacent angles on the same side of AB.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then sum of angles AOC and AOD are is equal to two right angles.
If lines AB and CD intersect at point O, then angles AOC and AOD are together equal to two right angles.
Adjacent angles which one straight line makes with another straight line on one side of it, are together equal to two right angles.
If two straight lines cut one another, the four angles so formed are together equal to four right angles.
If two straight lines cut one another, the four angles so formed are equal to four right angles.
Two angles are called complementary if their sum is equal to right angle.
If the sum of angles AOP and POB is equal to a right angle, then angles AOB and POB are called complementary angles.
If angles AOP and POB together equal a right angle, then angles AOB and POB are called complementary angles.
Angles AOP and POB are complementary angles.
Two angles are called complementary if their sum is equal to a right angle.
Two angles are called supplementary if their sum is equal to two right angles.
Two angles are called supplementary if their sum is equal to a straight angle.
If the sum of angles AOP and POB is equal to two right angles, then angles AOP and POB are called supplementary angles.
If angles AOP and POB together equal to two right angles, then angles AOP and POB are called supplementary angles.
Two angles are called supplementary if their sum is equal to a straight angle.
If the sum of angles AOP and POB is equal to a straight angle, then angle AOP and POB are called supplementary angles.
If angles AOP and POB together equal to a straight angle, then angles AOP and POB are called supplementary angles.
Angles AOP and POB are supplementary angles.
If two straight lines intersect forming four angles of which one is known to be a right angle, prove that the other three are also right angles.
In the triangle ABC the angles ABC, ACB are given equal. If the side BC is produced both ways, show that the exterior angles so formed are equal.
In the triangle ABC the angles ABC, ACB are given equal. If AB and AC are produced beyond the base, show that the exterior angles so formed are equal.
OP is the internal bisector of angle AOB.
OP is the internal angle bisector of angle AOB.
OP is the angle bisector of angle AOB.
OP is the external bisector of angle AOB.
OP is the external angle bisector of angle AOB.
OP and OQ are internal and external bisectors of angle AOB.
Prove that the bisectors of the adjacent angles which one straight line makes with another contain a right angle.
The internal and external bisector of an angle are at right angle to one another.
If OP and OQ are internal and external bisectors of angle AOB, then angle AOP and angle COQ are complementary.
If OP and OQ are internal and external bisectors of angle AOB, then show that the angles BOP and COP are supplementary.
If OP and OQ are internal and external bisectors of angle AOB, then show that the angles AOQ and BOQ are supplementary.
If two straight lines cut one another, the vertically opposite angles are equal.
If from O, a point in AB, two straight lines OC, OD are drawn on opposite sides of AB so as to make the angle COB equal to the angle AOD. Show that OC and OD are in the same straight line.
Two straight lines AB, CD cross at O. If OX is the bisector of the angle BOD, prove that XO produced bisects the angle AOC.
A triangle is a plane figure bounded by three straight lines.
A quadrilateral is a plane figure bounded by four straight lines.
ABCD is a polygon with four sides.
ABCD is a  four-sided polygon.
ABCD is a quadrilateral.
ABC is a polygon with three sides.
ABC is a three-sided polygon.
ABCDE is a polygon with five sides.
ABCDE is a five-sided polygon.
ABCDE is a pentagon.
ABCDEF is a polygon with six sides.
ABCDEF is a six-sided polygon.
ABCDEF is a hexagon.
A triangle is equilateral if all its sides are equal.
A triangle is equiangular if all its angles are equal.
A triangle is regular when it is both equilateral and equiangular.
ABC is regular triangle.
If a triangle is equiangular, then it is also equilateral.
If a triangle is equilateral, then it is also equiangular.
A quadrilateral is equilateral if all its sides are equal.
ABCD is a rhombus.
A quadrilateral is equiangular if all its angles are equal.
ABCD is a rectangle.
A quadrilateral is regular when it is both equilateral and equiangular.
If ABCD is a quadrilateral, then AC and BD are called diagnols.
ABCD is a regular quadrilateral.
ABCD is a square.
A triangle is isosceles if two of its sides are equal.
ABC is a right-angled triangle.
ABC is a obtuse-angled triangle.
ABC is a acute-angled triangle.
A triangle is scalene if all its sides are unequal.
In any triangle the straight line joining a vertex to the middle point of the opposite side is called a median.
In any triangle the straight line joining a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side is called a median.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are equilateral and congruent.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are equilateral and equal in all respects.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are isosceles and congruent.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are isosceles and equal in all respects.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are scalene and congruent.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are scalene and equal in all respects.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are congruent.
Triangles ABC and XYZ are equal in all respects.
If two triangles have two sides of the one equal to two sides of the other, each to each, and the angles included by those sides equal, then the triangles are equal in all respects.
If two triangles have two sides of the one equal to two sides of the other, each to each, and the angles included by those sides equal, then the triangles are congruent.
Show that the bisector of the vertical angle of an isosceles triangle bisects the base.
Show that the bisector of the vertical angle of an isosceles triangle is perpendicular to the base.
Let O be the middle point of a straight line AB, and let OC be perpendicular to it. If P is any point in OC, prove that PA = PB.
A quadrilateral all whose sides are equal and all whose angles are right angles is called a square.
A quadrilateral all whose sides are equal and whose opposite sides are parallel is called a rhombus.
A quadrilateral whose opposite sides are equal and all whose angles are right angles is called a rectangle.
A quadrilateral whose opposite sides are equal and parallel is called a parallelogram.
In a square ABCD, the diagnols AC and BD are equal.
ABCD is a square, and L, M, and N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CD. Prove that LM = MN.
ABCD is a square, and L, M, and N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CD. Prove that AM = DM.
ABCD is a square, and L, M, and N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CD. Prove that AN = AM.
ABCD is a square, and L, M, and N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CD. Prove that BN = DM.
ABC is an isosceles triangle. From the equal sides AB, AC two equal parts AX, AY are cut off, and BY and CX are joined. Prove that BY = CX.
The angles at the base of an isosceles triangle are equal.
If the equal sides AB, AC of an isosceles triangle are produced, the exterior angles EBC, FCB are equal.
If the equal sides AB, AC of an isosceles triangle are produced, the exterior angles EBC, FCB are equal, for they are the supplements of the equal angles at the base.
ABC is a an isosceles triangle with AB and AC being the equal sides. Angle BAC is called the vertical angle.
ABC is a an isosceles triangle with AB and AC being the equal sides. A is called the vertex.
An isosceles triangle is symmetrical about the bisector of its vertical angle.
An equilateral triangle is symmetrical about the bisector of any of its angles.
ABCD is a four-sided figure whose sides are all equal, and the diagonal BD is drawn. Show that the angle ABD = the angle ADB.
ABCD is a four-sided figure whose sides are all equal, and the diagonal BD is drawn. Show that the angle CBD = the angle CDB.
ABCD is a four-sided figure whose sides are all equal. Show that the angle ABC = the angle ADC.
ABC, DBC are two isosceles triangles drawn on the same base BC, but on opposite sides of it. Prove that the angle ABD = the angle ACD.
ABC, DBC are two isosceles triangles drawn on the same base BC and on the same side of it. Prove that the angle ABD = the angle ACD.
AB, AC are the equal sides of an isosceles triangle ABC and L, M, N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CA respectively. Prove that LM = NM.
AB, AC are the equal sides of an isosceles triangle ABC and L, M, N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CA respectively. Prove that BN = CL.
AB, AC are the equal sides of an isosceles triangle ABC and L, M, N are the middle points of AB, BC, and CA respectively. Prove that the angle ALM = the angle ANM.
If two angles of a triangle are equal to one another, then the sides which are opposite to the equal angles are equal to one another.
An equiangular triangle is also equilateral.
If a triangle is equiangular then it is also equilateral.
If two triangles have the three sides of the one equal to the three sides of the other, each to each, they are equal in all respects.
If two triangles have the three sides of the one equal to the three sides of the other, each to each, they are congruent.
If two triangles have the three sides of the one equal to the three sides of the other, the triangles are equiangular to one another.
Show that the straight line which joins the vertex of an isosceles triangle to the middle point of the base, bisects the vertical angle.
Show that the straight line which joins the vertex of an isosceles triangle to the middle point of the base, is perpendicular to the base.
If ABCD is a rhombus show by drawing the diagonals AC, BD, that the angle ABC = the angle ADC.
If ABCD is a rhombus show by drawing the diagonals AC, BD, that AC bisects each of the angles BAD, BCD.
If ABCD is a rhombus show by drawing the diagonals AC, BD, that the diagonals bisect one another at right angles.
If in a quadrilateral ABCD the opposite sides are equal, namely AB = CD and AD = CB. Prove that the angle ADC = the angle ABC.
If ABC and DBC are two isosceles triangles drawn on the same side of same base BC, prove that the angle ABD = the angle ACD.
If ABC and DBC are two isosceles triangles drawn on the opposite sides of the same base BC, prove that the angle ABD = the angle ACD.
If ABC, DBC are two isosceles triangles drawn on opposite sides of the same base BC, and if AD be joined, prove that each of the angles BAC, BDC will be divided into two equal parts.
Show that the straight lines which join the extremities of the base of an isosceles triangle to the middle points of the opposite sides are equal to one another.
Two given points in the base of an isosceles triangle are equidistant from the extremities of the base. Show that they are also equidistant from the vertex.
Show that the triangle formed by joining the middle points of the sides of an equilateral triangle is also equilateral.
Show that the diagnols of a Rhombus bisect one another at right angles.
The equal sides BA, CA of an isosceles triangle BAC are produced beyond the vertex A to the points E and F, so that AE is equal to AF and FB, EC are joined. Show that FB is equal to EC.
If one side of a triangle is produced, then the exterior angle is greater than either of the interior opposite angles.
ABC is a triangle. If the side AB is produced in one direction to X, then the exterior angle XCB is greater than either of the interior opposite angles ABC and BAC.
Every triangle must have at least two acute angles.
Only one perpendicular can be drawn to a straight line from a given point outside it.
If AB is a straight line and O is a point outside AB then only one perpendicular can be drawn from O to AB.
Only one perpendicular can be drawn from a point to a straight line not passing through that point.
The perpendicular drawn from point O to the line AB is the shortest distance from O to AB.
ABC is a triangle and D any point within it. If BD and CD are joined, the angle BDC is greater than the angle BAC. Prove this by producing BD to meet AC.
ABC is a triangle and D any point within it. If BD and CD are joined, the angle BDC is greater than the angle BAC. Prove this by joining AD, and producing it towards the base.
If any side of a triangle is produced both ways, the exterior angles so formed are together greater than two right angles.
ABC is a triangle. If BC is produced in both directions to X and Y, the exterior angles ABX and ACY are together greater than two right angles.
To a given straight line there cannot be drawn from a point outside it more than two straight lines of the same given length.
If the equal sides of an isosceles triangle are produced, the exterior angles must be obtuse.
If one side of a triangle is greater than another, then the angle opposite to the greater side is greater than the angle opposite to the lesser side.
If one angle of a triangle is greater than another, then the side opposite to the greater angle is greater than the side opposite to the lesser angle.
Any two sides of a triangle are together greater than the third side.
The shortest distance between two points is the straight line which joins them.
The shortest distance points A and B is the line AB.
Of all straight lines drawn from a given point to a given straight line the perpendicular is the least.
If OC is the shortest straight line from O to AB, then OC is perpendicular to AB.
Two obliques OP, OQ, which cut AB at equal distances from C, the foot of the perpendicular, are equal.
If OP and OQ are oblique lines from O to AB such that CP is equal to CQ where OC is the perpendicular from O to AB, then OP and OQ are also equal.
Of two obliques OQ, OR, if OR cuts AB at the greater distance from C, the foot of the perpendicular, then OR is greater than OQ.
The hypotenuse is the greatest side of a right-angled triangle.
If ABC is a right triangle with angle ABC as the right angle, then AC is called the hypotenuse.
If ABC is a right triangle with angle ABC as the right angle, then AC is the greatest side.
The greatest side of any triangle makes acute angles with each of the other sides.
If from the ends of a side of a triangle, two straight lines are drawn to a point within the triangle, then these straight lines are together less than the other two sides of the triangle.
BC, the base of an isosceles triangle ABC, is produced to any point D. Show that AD is greater than either of the equal sides.
If in a quadrilateral the greatest and least sides are opposite to one another, then each of the angles adjacent to the least side is greater than its opposite angle.
In a triangle ABC, if AC is not greater than AB, show that any straight line drawn through the vertex A and terminated by the base BC, is less than AB.
The difference of any two sides of a triangle is less than the third side.
The sum of the distances of any point from the three angular points of a triangle is greater than half its perimeter.
The sum of the distances of any point within a triangle from its angular points is less than the perimeter of the triangle.
In a triangle any two sides are together greater than twice the median which bisects the remaining side. Prove by producing the median.
In any triangle the sum of the medians is less than the perimeter.
The perimeter of a quadrilateral is greater than the sum of its diagnols.
Lines in the same plane that do not meet however far they are produced beyond both ends are called parallel straight lines.
Two intersecting straight lines cannot both be parallel to a third straight line.
Through a given point there can be only one straight line parallel to a given straight line.
When two straight lines AB, CD are met by a third straight line EF, eight angles are formed.
When two straight lines AB, CD are crossed by a third straight line EF, eight angles are formed.
When two straight lines AB, CD are intersected by a third straight line EF, eight angles are formed.
When two straight lines AB, CD are met by a third straight line EF at points X and Y, angles AXE, EXB, CYF, FYD are called exterior angles.
When two straight lines AB, CD are met by a third straight line EF at points X and Y, angles AXY, BXY, CYX, DYX are called interior angles.
A straight line drawn across a set of given lines is called a transversal.
If a straight line cuts two parallel lines, it makes the alternate angles equal to one another.
If a straight line cuts two parallel lines, it makes the exterior angle equal to the interior opposite angle on the same side of the cutting line.
Parallel straight lines have the same direction but differ in position.
Through any point we may assume a line to pass parallel to any given straight line.
Straight lines which are parallel to the same straight line are parallel to one another.
Straight lines which are perpendicular to the same straight line are parallel to one another.
If a straight line meets two or more parallel straight lines, and is perpendicular to one of them, it is also perpendicular to all the others.
A radius of a circle is a straight line drawn from the centre to the circumference.
All the radii of a circle are equal.
Any two radii of a circle are equal.
If OA and OB are two radii of a circle, then they are equal.
A diameter of a circle is a straight line drawn through the centre and terminated both ways by the circumference.
A semicircle is a figure bounded by a diameter of a circle and the part of the circumference cut off by the diameter.
Circles that have the same centre are said to be concentric.
A circle is a closed curve so that if the circumference is crossed by a straight line, this line if produced will cross the circumference at a second point.
Circles of equal radii are identically equal.
Concentric circles of unequal radii cannot intersect.
An arc of a circle is any part of the circumference.
A chord of a circle is a straight line, joining any two points on the circumference.
A chord of a circle, which does not pass through the centre, divides the circumference into two unequal arcs. Of these, the greater is called the major arc, and the less minor arc.
The major and minor arcs, into which a circumference is divided by a chord, are said to be conjugate to one another.

Let AB be a straight line and P a point outside it. From P draw PM perpendicular to AB, and produce it to Q, making MQ equal to PM. The points P and Q are said to be symmetrically opposite with regard to the axis AB, and each point is said to be the image of the other in the axis.
A point and its image are equidistant from every point on the axis.
A circle is symmetncal about any diameter.
A circle has O as the center and AB as any diameter. Prove that the circle is symmetrical about AB.
If a circle passes through a given point P, it also passes through the symmetrically opposite point with regard to any diameter.
In equal circles angles at the centre which stand on equal arcs are equal.
In equal circles arcs which subtend equal angles at the centre are equal.
In equal circles arcs which are cut off by equal chords are equal, the major arc to the major and the minor arc to the minor.
In equal circles chords which cut off equal arcs are equal.
In equal circles sectors which have equal angles are equal.
If a straight line drawn from the center of a circle bisects a chord which does not pass through the center, it cuts the chord at right angles.
If a straight line drawn from the center of a circle cuts the chord at right angles, which does not pass through the center, it bisects the chord.
Let ABC be a circle whose centre is O and let OD bisect a chord AB which does not pass through the centre. Prove that OD is perpendicular to AB.
The straight line which bisects a chord at right angles passes through the centre.
A straight line cannot meet a circle at more than two points.
A chord of a circle lies wholly within it.
One circle, and only one, can pass through any three points not in the same straight line.
The size and position of a circle are fully determined if three of its points are known.
The circle passing through the vertices of a triangle is said to be circumscribed about the triangle. The circle is called the circumcircle of the triangle.
The circle passing through the vertices of a triangle is said to be circumscribed about the triangle. The circle's radius are called the circumradius of the triangle.
The circle passing through the vertices of a triangle is said to be circumscribed about the triangle. The circle's centre is called the circumcenter of the triangle.
The parts of a straight line intercepted between the circumferences of two concentric circles are equal.
Two circles, whose centres are at A and B, intersect at C, D and M is the middle point of the common chord. Show that AM and BM are in the same straight line.
Two circles, whose centres are at A and B, intersect at C, D and M is the middle point of the common chord. Prove that the line of centres bisects the common chord at right angles.
AB, AC are two equal chords of a circle, show that the straight line which bisects the angle BAC passes through the centre.
Find the locus of the centres of all circles which pass through two given points.
Describe a circle that shall pass through two given points and have its centre in a given straight line.
Describe a circle of given radius to pass through two given points.
If from a point within a circle more than two equal straight lines can he drawn to the circumference, that point is the centre of the circle.

Let ABC be a circle, and O a point within it from which more than two equal straight lines are drawn to the circumference, namely OA,OB,OC. It is required to prove that O is the centre of the circle ABC.
Equal chords of a circle are equidistant from the centre.
Chords which are equidistant from the centre are equal.
Find the locus of the middle points of equal chords of a circle.
If two chords of a circle cut one another, and make equal angles with the straight line which joins their point of intersection to the centre, they are equal.
If two equal chords of a circle intersect, show that the segments of the one are equal respectively to the segments of the other.
In a given circle draw a chord which shall be equal to one given straight line (not greater than the diameter) and parallel to another.
PQ is a fixed chord in a circle, and AB is any diameter. Show that the sum or difference of the perpendiculars let fall from A and B on PQ is the same for all positions of AB.
Of any two chords of a circle, that which is nearer to the center is greater than one more remote.
The greater of two chords is nearer to the centre than the less.
The greatest chord in a circle is a diameter.
Through a given point within a circle draw the least possible chord.
The angle at the centre of a circle is double of an angle at the circumference standing on the same arc.
A segment of a circle is the figure bounded by a chord and one of the two arcs into which the chord divides the circumference.
The chord of a segment is called its base.
An angle in a segment is one formed by two straight lines drawn from any point in the arc of the segment to the extremities of its chord.
If four or more points are so placed that a circle may be drawn through them, they are said to be concyclic.
All circles which pass through a fixed point, and have their centres on a given straight line, pass also through a second fixed point.
If two circles which intersect are cut by a straight line parallel to the common chord, show that the parts of it intercepted between the circumferences are equal.
If two circles cut one another, any two parallel straight lines drawn through the points of intersection to cut the circles are equal.
Find the greatest straight line which has one extremity on each of two given non-intersecting circles.
Find the least straight line which has one extremity on each of two given non-intersecting circles.
If from any point on the circumference of a circle straight lines are drawn to the circumference, the greatest is that which passes through the centre.
If from any point on the circumference of a circle straight lines are drawn to the circumference, then of any two such lines the greater is that which subtends the greater angle at the centre.
Of all straight lines drawn through a point of intersection of two circles and terminated by the circumferences, the greatest is that which is parallel to the line of centres.

If from any internal point, not the centre, straight lines are drawn to the circumference of a circle, then the greatest is that which passes through the centre and the least is the remaining part of that diameter.
If from any internal point, not the centre, straight lines are drawn to the circumference of a circle then of any two such lines the greater is that which subtends the greater angle at the center.

If from any external point straight lines are drawn to the circumference of a circle, the greatest is that which passes through the centre, and the least is that which when produced passes through the centre
If from any external point straight lines are drawn to the circumference of a circle then of any other two such lines, the greater is that which subtends the greater angle at the centre.
Prove that the angle in a semicircle is a right angle.
The angle in, a segment of a circle greater than a semicircle is an acute angle.
The angle in a segment of a circle less than a semicircle is an obtuse angle.
A circle described on the hypotenuse of a right triangle as diameter, passes through the opposite angular point.
Two circles intersect at A and B and through A two diameters AP, AQ are drawn, one in each circle. Show that the points P, B, Q are collinear.
A circle is described on one of the equal sides of an isosceles triangle as diameter. Show that it passes through the middle point of the base.
Circles described on any two sides of a triangle as diameters intersect on the third side, or the third side produced.
Find the locus of the middle points of chords of a circle drawn through a fixed point, when the given point is within the circumference.
Find the locus of the middle points of chords of a circle drawn through a fixed point, when the given point is on the circumference.
Find the locus of the middle points of chords of a circle drawn through a fixed point, when the given point is without the circumference.
The sum of the arcs cut off by two chords of a circle at right angles to one another is equal to the semi circumference.
